awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION

This award is to support the 2022 Vibrational Spectroscopy Gordon Research Seminar and Gordon Research Conference, to be held July 30 through August 5, 2022. The conference will provide a forum to highlight the unique role of vibrational spectroscopy in understanding structure, dynamics, and function of materials in complex, anisotropic environments. The unique format of a Gordon Research Conference will provide an opportunity to define the core community and address evolving challenges that are critical to current and future research efforts. The Gordon Research Conference will facilitate concentrated and vibrant discussions between the speakers and the audience. The Conference includes a diverse program of invited speakers and will provide numerous opportunities for early career researchers to build their networks and showcase their research. This award will provide support for eight early career scientists from underrepresented groups, including underrepresented minorities, women, and individuals with disabilities.

TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION

The conference seeks to make a connection between the fundamental behavior of matter at a molecular level with particular emphasis on how complex, dynamic, and crowded environments alter and affect molecular behavior. The unifying theme is cutting-edge spectroscopies that exploit vibrational signatures to probe the structures, dynamics, reactivity, and environments of molecules in gases, clusters, aerosols, liquids and solid materials, and at the interfaces between different materials. This conference will advance knowledge by emphasizing the use of established vibrational spectroscopic techniques to study new and challenging heterogeneous systems of interest. The conference will also advance knowledge by presenting emerging topics in the field, such as vibrational microscopy and novel methods for computing and simulating vibrational spectra. Advances in theory and simulations of vibrational spectra will be interwoven with experimental presentations to promote an open dialog between experimentalists and theoreticians. The program includes a mechanism to assess the success of the conference in achieving its goals and for improvements in future years.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The 2022 Vibrational Spectroscopy Gordon Research Conference (GRC), “Unravelling Chemical Heterogeneity,” highlighted the unique role of vibrational spectroscopy in investigating structure, dynamics, and function of materials in complex, anisotropic environments.

Intellectual Merit

The technical program of this conference advanced knowledge in the field of vibrational spectroscopy by emphasizing: 1) established methods to interrogate complex heterogeneous systems; and 2) new methodologies for emerging problems to push vibrational spectroscopy into new areas.

Established Methodologies: The application of established techniques to study heterogeneous systems resides at the cutting edge of the field and requires practitioners to implement new and creative approaches to data collection and theoretical modeling. Topics presented included the use of advanced vibrational spectroscopy and complementary theoretical techniques to study the structure, interactions, and dynamics of charged liquids and interfaces, catalytic systems, biomolecules in solution and at interfaces, and applications in environmental chemistry. These topics are important to a wide-range of fields such as combustion, atmospheric and biological chemistry, chemical energy storage and release, as well as fundamental questions relevant to a molecular level understanding of, for example, the properties of interfaces between phases, or the way that solvents interact with solutes. 

Emerging Topics: The 2022 program highlighted new applications of vibrational spectroscopy in microscopy, nanoscience, and novel methods for computing and simulating vibrational spectra. Presented topics in this area included the use of high electric fields at plasmonic surfaces to enhance vibrational signals and drive chemical reactivity, and the use of tunable cavities to explore the impact of strong coupling between cavity modes and molecular vibrations on intramolecular energy transfer. There were multiple talks from group leaders working at the frontier of vibrational spectroscopy using electron beams rather than photons, giving the ability to obtain vibrational spectra with nanoscopic spatial resolution. This is potentially transformative to the field, allowing scientists to cut through the complexity of heterogeneous systems and answer key questions about molecular structure and chemical reactivity. Emerging topics also highlighted experts pioneering new theoretical descriptions and computer simulations of vibrational spectra and dynamics to complement experimental perspectives and offer new scientific insights. Theoretical talks were interwoven with experimental presentations to promote an open dialog between experimentalists and theoreticians.   

Broader Impacts 

The topics presented and discussed at this GRC have the potential to lead to new fundamental understanding of the behavior of materials that are important for energy conversion and storage, biological devices, water remediation, and chemical catalysis. These are just a few of the myriad areas where vibrational spectroscopy can be a benefit to society as a whole. In addition, this GRC highlighted cutting-edge developments in the use of advanced theoretical and computational methods to explore molecular motions, chemical reactivity, catalysis, and the interactions of molecules with complex and dynamic heterogeneous environments. The speaker list was comprised of 47% female scientists and 43% international scientists from universities, national laboratories, and government agencies. Funding for this conference supported the attendance of scientists from underrepresented groups.
